AS this is my second post and the number of debate options is enormous, I thought I would throw in my opinion as it regards the "passport" issue that was recently in the news. I apologize if this has already been addressed. However, was anyone else bothered by the fact that once again, our President, who doesn'r read papers, found out about this isuue from the Newspaper? I mean really, first Abu Ghraib, and now this? What's next? 
 
 "I didn't know we were "this close" to getting Bin Laden at Tora Bora!"?
 
 OK, who is really in charge up there? Inquiring minds wan to know.

post_info.post_title: George "Dubya", "I Heard It Through The Grapevine"

Certainly not George ( I dont read Newspapers) Bush. It certainly seems that the decision for GWB not to read newspapers was not his own. 
 
 
 When ever he reads a newspaper he does seem to find a suprise regarding US policy.
 
 by the way it would have been better to place a link to the site regarding the passport and newspaper
 
 http://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&e=5&u=/ap/20050415/ap_on_go_pr_wh/bush_passports&sid=84439559
 

 The president said Thursday he was surprised by the proposed rules announced last week by the State and Homeland Security departments. 
 
 
 "When I first read that in the newspaper about the need to have passports, particularly today's crossings that take place, about a million for instance in the state of Texas, I said, `What's going on here?'" Bush said when asked about the rules at a meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. 
 
 

 
 I would think that most people would want a better informed president. A presidnet should not be suprised by US government policy

 My take on this is that Bush says the first thing that comes to mind. Chances are he was briefed on this at one time and it slipped by without being fully discussed. When he saw it in print, he said what came immediately to mind. And then the press goes to work to make a mountain out of a molehill. And then there are some top level bureaucrats that simply get carried away. I think this story likely is less than meets the eye.

My take on this is that Bush says the first thing that comes to mind. Chances are he was briefed on this at one time and it slipped by without being fully discussed. When he saw it in print, he said what came immediately to mind. And then the press goes to work to make a mountain out of a molehill. And then there are some top level bureaucrats that simply get carried away. I think this story likely is less than meets the eye.

 
 Well, I guess that excuses the whole "I look like I don't know what's going on in my own administration" thing that seems to be portrayed. I'm satisfied, and I thank you for clearing it up and making me feel better.
